definitions: having parents or ancestors from two different racial or ethnic backgrounds
examples: Their biracial children embrace both cultural traditions
She's proud of her biracial identity and heritage

definitions: constructed from or consisting of wood from birch trees
having the pale, light color characteristic of birch wood
examples: The birch cabinets brighten the entire kitchen space
We bought birch plywood for the new shelving
Her birch blonde hair caught everyone's attention immediately
The walls were painted in a soft birch tone

definitions: sexually attracted to both men and women; having romantic interest in multiple genders
examples: The bisexual community advocates for greater visibility and acceptance
She came out as bisexual during her college years

definitions: causing sharp discomfort from cold wind or low temperature
expressing criticism in a sharp, cutting, and often hurtful manner
examples: The biting wind made everyone hurry inside quickly
A biting frost killed all the tender garden plants
Her biting commentary left the audience stunned and silent
His biting wit often hurt people's feelings unintentionally

definitions: having a sharp, acrid taste that is generally unpleasant
feeling or showing anger, hurt, and resentment from disappointment
extremely cold in a way that causes physical discomfort
causing or characterized by severe pain, grief, or disappointment
examples: The bitter medicine made the child grimace and complain
Black coffee tastes too bitter without any sugar added
She remained bitter about the unfair promotion decision
Their bitter divorce battle lasted for three years
The bitter winter killed many homeless people that year
A bitter wind swept through the empty streets
It was a bitter defeat after months of preparation
The bitter truth finally came out during testimony

definitions: containing or arousing both pleasure and pain, happiness and sadness simultaneously
examples: Graduation was a bittersweet moment for the parents
The bittersweet ending left moviegoers emotionally conflicted

definitions: occurring or appearing once every two weeks; fortnightly
occurring or appearing two times within a single week
examples: Our biweekly meetings happen on alternate Monday mornings
She receives her biweekly paycheck every other Friday
The biweekly yoga classes meet Tuesdays and Thursdays
His biweekly column appears Wednesday and Saturday mornings

definitions: markedly unusual in appearance, style, or character; strikingly unconventional and odd
examples: The bizarre sculpture attracted curious crowds of onlookers
Her bizarre behavior at dinner worried her friends

definitions: of the very darkest color owing to absence of light reflection
relating to people of African origin or descent
characterized by complete absence of light; unilluminated
thoroughly sinister, evil, or wicked in nature or effect
involving illegal, unofficial, or unregulated trade or activity
examples: She wore a black dress to the formal event
The black car absorbed heat in the summer sun
Black authors have enriched American literature for centuries
The museum celebrates Black history and cultural achievements
The cave was black without any source of light
On moonless nights the forest becomes completely black
His black heart showed no mercy to anyone
They practiced black magic in secret midnight rituals
The black market thrived during the trade embargo
Black economy transactions avoid all government taxation

definitions: turned black or very dark through staining, weathering, or deliberate coloring
charred or scorched black from fire, heat, or burning
examples: The blackened walls showed years of smoke damage
His blackened hands revealed hours of mechanical work
The blackened fish was perfectly seasoned with Cajun spices
Blackened ruins stood where the house once was

definitions: having a color that is nearly but not quite black; darkish
examples: The bruise turned a blackish purple after several days
Blackish clouds gathered before the storm arrived

definitions: equipped with or characterized by having one or more cutting edges or blades
examples: The three-bladed propeller spun rapidly during takeoff
Multi-bladed razors provide a closer, smoother shave

definitions: worthy of blame or censure; responsible for something wrong or bad
examples: The blame party refused to accept any responsibility
Those blame fools caused the entire system failure

definitions: assigned responsibility or fault for something negative or wrong
used as a mild oath or expression of annoyance; confounded
examples: The blamed employee was fired despite weak evidence
She felt unfairly blamed for the team's poor performance
That blamed dog keeps digging up my garden
I can't find my blamed keys anywhere today

definitions: free from blame or guilt; having done nothing wrong or improper
examples: The investigation proved she was completely blameless
His blameless reputation helped during the false accusations

definitions: lacking strong flavor, taste, or seasoning; mild to the point of tastelessness
lacking distinctive or interesting features or characteristics; dull and unremarkable
examples: The bland hospital food needed salt and pepper
She prefers bland dishes due to her sensitive stomach
His bland personality made him forgettable at parties
The bland office decor desperately needed some color

definitions: having no marks, writing, or decoration; empty and available for use
showing no emotion, understanding, or interest in facial expression
complete and absolute; utter with no qualification or exception
examples: Please sign your name on the blank line below
She stared at the blank page unable to write
His blank expression revealed nothing about his thoughts
She gave him a blank look of total confusion
It was a blank refusal with no room for negotiation
The team faced blank disappointment after their loss

definitions: applying to or covering all cases, instances, or members without exception
examples: The company issued a blanket denial of all allegations
They imposed a blanket ban on mobile phones

definitions: covered completely with a layer of something, especially thickly or extensively
examples: The mountains were blanketed with fresh snow overnight
Fog blanketed streets made driving extremely dangerous

definitions: expressing disrespect or irreverence toward God, sacred things, or religious beliefs
examples: His blasphemous remarks offended the religious community deeply
The blasphemous artwork was removed from the gallery

definitions: damaged, destroyed, or affected by an explosion or strong force
used to express annoyance or for emphasis; confounded or damned
examples: The blasted building stood as a war memorial
Blasted rock fragments littered the construction site
This blasted computer keeps freezing every few minutes
I can't open this blasted jar no matter what

definitions: producing an extremely loud, powerful, or overwhelming sound or force
expressing harsh, severe criticism or condemnation
examples: The blasting music could be heard three blocks away
Blasting heat from the furnace filled the room
The senator delivered a blasting speech against corruption
Her blasting review destroyed the restaurant's reputation

definitions: done openly and unashamedly; very obvious and offensive in an intentional way
examples: His blatant lie fooled nobody in the courtroom
The blatant favoritism upset other team members greatly

definitions: burning with bright flames or fire; on fire vigorously
extremely hot, especially from sunshine or high temperature
showing or feeling intense anger or other strong emotion
examples: The blazing fire destroyed three houses before containment
Blazing torches lit the medieval castle entrance
The blazing sun made outdoor work nearly impossible
We endured blazing temperatures throughout the desert journey
Her blazing eyes showed her fury at the betrayal
They had a blazing argument about money again

definitions: made white or lighter by chemical treatment or processing
made pale or colorless by prolonged exposure to sunlight
examples: Her bleached hair contrasted with her dark eyebrows
The bleached sheets smelled fresh and clean
The bleached bones lay scattered across the desert
Years of sun left the curtains thoroughly bleached

definitions: exposed to cold wind and weather; bare and inhospitable
offering little hope, happiness, or encouragement; depressing and dismal
examples: The bleak moorland stretched endlessly under gray skies
A bleak wind swept across the barren landscape
Her bleak future offered no opportunities for advancement
The economic forecast looks increasingly bleak this quarter

definitions: mixed or combined together into a uniform mixture or substance
combined smoothly and harmoniously without sharp transitions or contrasts
examples: The blended coffee combines beans from three countries
Use blended fabrics for better durability and comfort
Their blended family works surprisingly well together
The blended learning approach combines online and classroom instruction

definitions: made holy or consecrated; favored by God or divine grace
bringing pleasure, contentment, or good fortune; welcome and beneficial
used as a mild expression of annoyance; confounded or damned
examples: The blessed Virgin Mary holds special significance for Catholics
He lived a blessed life of service and prayer
We've been blessed with beautiful weather this week
The blessed relief of air conditioning saved us
I can't find my blessed glasses anywhere again
That blessed cat knocked over another plant today

definitions: affected by plant disease that causes withering and death
damaged, ruined, or spoiled, especially by adverse conditions
examples: The blighted corn crop meant financial disaster for farmers
Blighted trees were removed from the orchard immediately
The blighted neighborhood suffered from decades of neglect
His blighted career never recovered from the scandal

definitions: unable to see because of injury, disease, or congenital condition
unwilling or unable to perceive or understand; lacking awareness
concealed from sight; providing concealment or cover
not based on reason or evidence; unthinking and unquestioning
examples: The blind musician developed extraordinary hearing abilities
She's been blind since birth but lives independently
He remained blind to his own shortcomings and faults
They were blind to the danger approaching them
A blind corner caused many accidents at that intersection
The hunter waited in his blind spot patiently
Blind faith led them to follow the charismatic leader
Her blind rage destroyed everything in its path

definitions: deprived of sight temporarily or permanently by bright light or injury
made unable to think clearly or understand due to strong emotion
examples: The explosion left him temporarily blinded by the flash
She was blinded by the oncoming car's headlights
He was blinded by jealousy and couldn't see the truth
Love had blinded her to his obvious faults

definitions: having the eyes covered with cloth to prevent seeing
examples: The blindfold test proved which cola they preferred
Children played blindfold games at the birthday party

definitions: having a cloth or covering over the eyes preventing vision
examples: The blindfolded hostages were led to safety carefully
She correctly identified spices while blindfolded

definitions: so bright as to obscure vision or cause temporary inability to see
so intense or extreme as to overwhelm the senses or understanding
examples: The blinding snow made driving impossible on the highway
A blinding flash preceded the thunder by seconds
She felt blinding pain shoot through her injured knee
His blinding speed left defenders completely beaten

definitions: shining with a light that repeatedly turns on and off
used as a mild oath to express annoyance; confounded
examples: The blinking lights on the tower warn approaching aircraft
A blinking cursor shows where text will appear
This blinking machine won't work properly no matter what
I've lost my blinking wallet somewhere in this mess

definitions: experiencing or producing complete happiness and joy; perfectly content
examples: The couple spent blissful days on their honeymoon island
She lived in blissful ignorance of the problems

definitions: so hot as to cause blisters or extreme discomfort
expressing harsh criticism in an intense, scorching manner
extremely fast, intense, or forceful in pace or action
examples: The blistering desert heat reached 120 degrees Fahrenheit
Blistering pavement burned through their thin shoe soles
She delivered a blistering attack on government corruption
His blistering critique left the author devastated
The runner maintained a blistering pace throughout the race
They scored at a blistering rate in the finals

definitions: showing a casual cheerful indifference; happy and carefree
showing insufficient thought or consideration; heedlessly casual
examples: Her blithe spirit lifted everyone's mood at work
He maintained a blithe attitude despite the difficulties
His blithe disregard for safety rules endangered everyone
She made blithe assumptions without checking the facts

definitions: swollen with fluid or gas; distended uncomfortably
excessive in size or amount; unnecessarily inflated
examples: He felt bloated after eating the large meal quickly
The bloated corpse was discovered floating in the river
The bloated budget exceeded projections by fifty percent
Their bloated bureaucracy slowed every decision to crawling pace

definitions: sealed off or surrounded to prevent goods or people from entering or leaving
examples: The blockaded port couldn't receive any supply ships
Blockaded streets prevented protesters from advancing further

definitions: engaged in sealing off or preventing access to an area or location
examples: The blockading ships prevented any vessels from entering
Blockading forces surrounded the city for three months

definitions: having the passage or progress obstructed; unable to move through
examples: The blocked drain caused water to overflow everywhere
Her blocked sinuses made breathing difficult all week

definitions: having a square, solid shape with angular rather than curved lines
examples: His blocky build made him perfect for playing football
The blocky architecture dominated the city's skyline

definitions: having hair of a pale yellowish or golden color
examples: His naturally blond hair lightened further in summer
The blond wood furniture brightened the entire room

definitions: having fair or pale yellow hair, traditionally used for females
examples: The blonde actress starred in numerous Hollywood films
She dyed her hair blonde for the summer months

definitions: having blood of a specified type or temperature
of pure breeding; having documented pedigree
examples: Cold-blooded animals regulate temperature through their environment
Warm-blooded creatures maintain constant body temperature
The blue-blooded aristocrat traced ancestry to medieval times
These hot-blooded horses excel at racing competitions

definitions: achieved without violence or killing; free from bloodshed
lacking vigor, emotion, or vitality; lifeless and dull
drained of color; extremely pale from lack of blood
examples: The bloodless revolution transferred power peacefully to democracy
They achieved a bloodless coup through careful negotiation
His bloodless prose failed to engage any readers emotionally
The bloodless performance left the audience completely unmoved
Her bloodless lips indicated severe loss of blood
His face turned bloodless when he heard the news

definitions: having red lines from dilated blood vessels, especially in eyes
examples: His bloodshot eyes revealed another sleepless night studying
The swimmer's bloodshot eyes resulted from chlorine exposure

definitions: marked, spotted, or covered with blood
examples: The bloodstained shirt became evidence in the trial
Bloodstained bandages filled the emergency room bins

definitions: eager to kill or see violence; taking pleasure in bloodshed or cruelty
examples: The bloodthirsty crowd demanded the gladiator's death
His bloodthirsty reputation preceded him into every battle
